questions.text: A chronic smoker presents with complaints of hemoptysis. Chest X-ray appears to be normal. What is the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

High-resolution CT

  • HRCT chest is a valuable diagnostic tool for evaluating COPD, lung cancer, and other pulmonary disorders.
  • In the case of a chronic smoker presenting with hemoptysis and a normal chest X-ray, HRCT can provide detailed images of the lung parenchyma and airways, allowing for the detection of subtle abnormalities that may not be apparent on a standard chest X-ray.
  • HRCT can help identify lung nodules, bronchiectasis, interstitial lung disease, and other structural changes associated with smoking-related lung disease or lung cancer.

Bronchoscopy (Option A), Sputum cytology (Option C) and Bronchoalveolar lavage (Option D), all can be used in the management, whereas HRCT will be the next best step in a case of hemoptysis with normal chest X-ray findings.

questions.text: Hilar markings in a normal chest X-ray are formed by all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hilar markings in a normal X-ray are formed by:
    • Pulmonary artery (Option A)
    • Bronchus (Option B)
    • Upper lobe veins (Option C)

Lower lobe veins do not contribute significantly to the hilar markings due to their posterior and inferior anatomical course, which usually lies outside the plane of the hilum on standard posteroanterior views.

questions.text: "Golden S" sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The "Golden S" sign is seen in the right upper lobe collapse.

  • The "Golden S sign" (also known as the reverse S sign of Golden) is a classical radiographic feature seen in cases of right upper lobe collapse, typically caused by an obstructing bronchogenic carcinoma.
  • The characteristic "S-shaped" appearance of the horizontal fissure on frontal chest radiographs arises from:
  • Inward and downward retraction of the horizontal fissure due to volume loss from upper lobe collapse.
  • Convex outward bulge due to a central obstructing mass lesion in the right upper lobe bronchus.
  • The sign is only seen on the right side because the horizontal fissure is anatomically present only in the right lung.

Explanation of other options:

Luftsichel sign seen in the Left upper lobe (Option B) collapse

Right middle lobe (Option C) pathologies - Silhouette of the Right heart border.

Lower lobe collapse (Option D): Collapse of either lower lobe does not involve the horizontal fissure and does not result in the S-shaped configuration.

choices.text: Pleural effusion of the right side

questions.text: A 41-year-old male presented with shortness of breath. The following Radiograph was taken. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • X-ray chest shows a large hyperlucent area with no vascular markings in the right hemithorax, with right lung collapse and mediastinal shift - large pneumothorax.
  • Pneumothorax refers to the presence of gas (air) in the pleural space.
  • When there is a progressive accumulation of intrapleural gas in the thoracic cavity (caused by a valve effect during inspiration and expiration), it is calleda tension pneumothorax.
  • It can result in compression of mediastinal structures and compromise cardiopulmonary function. It is life-threatening and requires emergency intervention.

CXR findings of pneumothorax:

  • Absent broncho-vascular markings
  • Visceral pleural line
  • Deep sulcus sign(supine CXR)

Explanation of other options:

Pulmonary embolism (Option B) - Wedge shaped filling defect in CTPA, Hampton's hump, Westermark sign, pallas sign, chang sign.

Poland syndrome (Option C)- congenital unilateral absence of the pectoralis major and minor muscles.

Pleural effusion of the right side (Option D): This is the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space. On a chest X-ray, pleural effusion typically appears as a homogenous opacity that starts at the lung base and rises towards the axilla in a meniscus shape (Ellis curve). It may obscure the costophrenic angle and cause a shift of the mediastinum if large.

questions.text: A patient of RTA with injuries over chest and limbs has low Sp02. A POC M- mode ultrasound of right upper part of chest shows absent lung sliding and barcode sign. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The absence of lung sliding and the presence of the barcode signon M-mode ultrasound are indicative of pneumothorax.
  • This condition occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space,causing the lung to collapse partially or completely.
  • In a trauma patient with injuries to the chest, the presence of low SpO2further supports the diagnosis, as it indicates potential respiratory compromise.
  • M-modeis defined as the time-motion display of the ultrasound wave along a chosen ultrasound line. With M-Mode, even rapid motions can be displayed, measured and recorded.
  • In a normal lung, the M-mode image demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural lineand a granular or sandy appearance deep to the pleural line.
  • The motionless portion of the chest above the pleural line creates horizontal 'waves',and the sliding below the pleural line creates a granular pattern, the 'sand'. The resultant picture resembles waves crashing onto the sand and is therefore called the 'seashore sign' and is present in a normal lung.
  • Stratosphere sign refersto M-mode showing a linear pattern below the pleural line. It is also called a barcode It is specific for pneumothorax.

Explanation of other options:

Haemothorax (Option A): Blunting of the costophrenic angle on chest X-ray with homogeneous opacity.

Cardiac tamponade (Option C): Enlarged cardiac silhouette with a 'Money bag/water bottle' shaped appearance on chest X-ray.

Pulmonary embolism (Option D): Hampton's hump or Westermark sign (Focal oligemia - radiograph below) on chest X-ray, indicating pulmonary infarction or vascular abnormalities.

questions.text: Pneumothorax is best demonstrated by taking a radiograph, with patient in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

End expiration

Pneumothorax is best demonstrated in the end-expiratory view, as small pneumothorax is sometimes missed on full inspiration. Hence, we recommend the expiratory view.

Expiratory chest X-ray is done in:

  • Pneumothorax
  • Conditions causing air trapping, like a foreign body, partial bronchial obstruction, etc
  • Diaphragmatic palsy

CXR findings of pneumothorax:

  • Absent broncho-vascular markings
  • Visceral pleural line
  • Deep sulcus sign(supine CXR)

Explanation of other options:
Mid inspiration (Option A): Not a standard radiographic phase; does not significantly aid detection of small pneumothoraces.

Full inspiration (Option C): The standard view, but may miss subtle or small pneumothoraces as the lung expands to fill the pleural space.

Supine (Option D): Often used in trauma patients, but in this position, air collects anteriorly and pneumothorax may be difficult to detect; instead, the deep sulcus sign is used.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented to the casualty after a road traffic accident. He has bruises on his chest. His pulse is 120 bpm. BP is 90/60 and RR is 40. A chest X-ray was performed and is shown below. What is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chest tube placement and drainage

  • The chest X-ray shows a pneumothoraxwith evidence of lung collapse, which is likely contributing to the patient's respiratory distress, indicated by the tachypnea and hypotension.
  • Chest tube placement and drainage are the standard treatment for a pneumothorax,especially if it is causing symptoms such as respiratory distress or hemodynamic instability.
  • The chest tube allows for the evacuation of air or fluid from the pleural space, re-expanding the lung and relieving pressure on the mediastinum and heart.

Explanation of other options:

Immediate thoracotomy (Option A) would be considered if the patient's condition deteriorates rapidly, leading to cardiac tamponade or tension pneumothorax, but it's not the initial step in managing a pneumothorax.

Pleurodesis (Option B) is typically performed as a secondary procedure to prevent the recurrence of spontaneous pneumothorax, but it's not indicated as the immediate intervention in an acute setting.

Pericardiocentesis (Option C) would be indicated if there were signs or symptoms of cardiac tamponade, such as hypotension, pulsus paradoxus, or electrical alternans, which are not evident in this scenario.

questions.text: A term neonate born by vacuum-assisted delivery developed respiratory distress after birth. Arterial oxygen saturation remained > 92% without supplemental oxygen. The X-ray performed after birth is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario and radiograph showing a spinnaker sign are suggestive of pneumomediastinum.

CXR findings of pneumomediastinum

  • Spinnaker Sail Sign (Angel Wing Sign) - characteristic of neonatal pneumomediastinum.
  • Continuous Diaphragm Sign- visualisation of the entire central diaphragm due to mediastinal air.
  • Naclerio's V Sign - air outlining the lateral border of the descending aorta and diaphragm.
  • Air around mediastinal structures - including aorta, pulmonary artery, bronchi, and trachea.
  • Boerhaave Syndrome (esophageal perforation) can also cause pneumomediastinum.
  • Thymic Sail Sign - a normal thymic variant, not to be confused with Spinnaker Sail.

Explanation of other options:

Pneumothorax (Option B): This is the presence of air in the pleural space, which leads to lung collapse. On a chest X-ray, pneumothorax appears as an area without lung markings between the lung margin and the chest wall. Deep sulcus sign. There may be a visible line representing the collapsed lung, and the affected side may appear more radiolucent.

Pneumoperitoneum (Option C) is the presence of free air peritoneal cavity as a result of Trauma/Hollow Viscus Perforation. A cupola sign air under the central tendon of the Diaphragm and is commonly seen with Hollow visceral perforation/Pneumoperitoneum.

Consolidation (Option D): This refers to the filling of the alveoli with fluid, resulting in a homogenous increase in pulmonary parenchymal density. On a chest X-ray, consolidation appears as a localised opacity that may obscure the margins of adjacent structures, such as the heart or diaphragm.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of dyspnea. A chest X-ray is advised and is shown. It is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pleural Effusion

  • This is the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space. On a chest X-ray, pleural effusion typically appears as a homogenous opacitythat starts at the lung base and rises towards the axilla in a meniscus shape (Ellis curve). It may obscure the costophrenic angle and cause a shift of the mediastinum if large.

Features of chest radiograph in pleural effusion:

  • Presence of free pleural fluid
  • Blunting of the costophrenic angle
  • Ellis-S curve- This is a radiological illusion and occurs as a medial radiological density due to the presence of a partially aerated lung between the anterior and posterior fluid layers, whereas laterally, the density is higher due to the presence of fluid only. The actual fluid level is horizontal.

The minimal amount of fluid required to be detected on imaging for pleural effusion:

  • Lateral view - 75 ml pleural fluid
  • PA view - 200 ml pleural fluid
  • Lateral decubitus - <25 ml pleural fluid

Explanation of other options:

Consolidation (Option A): This refers to the filling of the alveoli with fluid, resulting in a homogenous increase in pulmonary parenchymal density. On a chest X-ray, consolidation appears as a localised opacity that may obscure the margins of adjacent structures, such as the heart or diaphragm.

Pneumothorax (Option C): This is the presence of air in the pleural space, which leads to lung collapse. On a chest X-ray, pneumothorax appears as an area without lung markings between the lung margin and the chest wall. Deep sulcus sign. A visible line may represent the collapsed lung, and the affected side may appear more radiolucent.

Hydropneumothorax (Option D): This condition involves both air and fluid in the pleural space. On a chest X-ray, it presents with a horizontal fluid level and an air space above the fluid.

choices.text: It makes an obtuse angle with the chest wall
The margins are clear when viewed in face
Not confined to any bronchoPulmonary segment
Changes its shape with Change position

questions.text: All of the following are true about loculated pleural effusion except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Loculated pleural effusion doesn't change its shape with a Change in position.

Loculated pleural effusion,

  • D-shaped collection, Broad base towards the pleura.
  • It does not change position.
  • It makes an obtuse angle with the chest wall. (Option A)
  • The margins are clear (Option B) and are not confined to any bronchopulmonary segment (Option C).

questions.text: A patient presented with a fever. Radiological examination of the patient is as follows: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given X-ray shows a horizontal air-fluid level in the right hemithorax, which is diagnostic of hydropneumothorax.
  • This appearance is due to the simultaneous presence of both air and fluid in the pleural cavity.
  • It typically occurs following trauma, rupture of an abscess, or infection, and may present clinically with fever and respiratory distress.
  • The key radiological feature differentiating hydropneumothorax from pleural effusion or pneumothorax alone is the sharp horizontal interface.

Explanation of other options:

Pleural effusion (Option A) - Meniscus sign, Ellis curve, Obliteration of costophrenic angle

Pneumothorax (Option B)- Trachea shift to opposite side, Deep sulcus sign.

Lung abscess (Option D) - Large pulmonary cavity with a small dependent air-fluid level within the cavity.

questions.text: Loss of cardiac silhouette is seen in pathology of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Obliteration of right heart border (Loss of cardiac silhouette) - Right middle lobe pathology.
  • The principle of the silhouette sign is that the mediastinal borders can be obscured only by a pathology that is in direct anatomical contact.

Positive silhouette sign and corresponding anatomical site of pathology:

  • Right heart border - right middle lobe or medial right lower lobe
  • Left heart border - lingula segments of the left upper lobe
  • Left hemidiaphragm or descending aorta - left lower lobe
  • Aortic knuckle - left upper lobe (posterior segment)
  • Right hemidiaphragm - right lower lobe
  • Right paratracheal stripe - right upper lobe

Recognition of this sign is useful in localising areas of airspace opacities, atelectasis, or mass within the lung.


Explanation of other options:

The right lower lobe (Option B) lies posteriorly and does not obscure the cardiac silhouette.
Pathology here may cause obscuration of the right hemidiaphragm, not the heart border.

Right Atrium (Option C): Although the right atrium contributes to the cardiac silhouette, it is not a lung lobe and thus not the site of pulmonary opacity. The correct relationship is that pathology in the right middle lobe can obscure the right atrial border.

The right ventricle (Option D) forms the anterior surface of the heart, but not the right border. Pathologies here do not result in loss of the right cardiac contour on the frontal radiograph.

questions.text: Air bronchogram is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Consolidation

  • An air bronchogram is air filled bronchus with heterogeneous opacification around it due to collapse or fluid in the surrounding alveoli.
  • An air bronchogram is a radiologic sign seen on chest X-rays or CT scans where air-filled bronchi are outlined by an area of consolidation in the surrounding lung tissue.
  • Consolidation refers to the process where lung alveoli fill with fluid or inflammatory exudate, typically due to pneumonia or other conditions, causing lung tissue to become solidified rather than filled with air.

Causes of an Air Bronchogram

  • Consolidation/pneumonia
  • Pulmonary edema
  • ARDS/HMD
  • Bronchoalveolar Ca

Explanation of other options:

Lung abscess (Option A): Large pulmonary cavity with a small dependent air-fluid level within the cavity.

Pneumothorax (Option B): Trachea shift to the opposite side, Deep sulcus sign.

Pleural effusion (Option C): Meniscus sign, Ellis curve, Obliteration of costophrenic angle

questions.text: In an AIDS patient with suspected tuberculosis, the following chest X-ray is done; the most likely finding seen is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows the Miliary shadow pattern seen in an AIDS patient with miliary TB

  • In immunocompromised patients or at later stages with low CD4 counts, containment of TB is not possible, leading to a disseminated form of TB, like miliary TB.

Miliary mottling

  • Mitral Stenosis
  • Pulmonary hemosiderosis
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Sarcoidosis

Explanation of other options:-

Cavitation (Option B): Cavitary lesions appear as lucent areas within consolidated lung tissue, often surrounded by irregular walls. Common in post-primary TB or bacterial lung abscesses, a cavitary lesion is visible in this image. 

Consolidation (Option C) presents as homogeneous opacification due to alveolar filling with fluid, pus, blood, or cells.
Typically seen in pneumonia and is segmental or lobar, not diffusely scattered as in miliary TB.

Lymphadenopathy (Option D): Hilar or mediastinal lymphadenopathy may present as mediastinal widening or discrete masses.
It does not show diffuse parenchymal nodules like miliary TB.

questions.text: All of the following causes the following appearance on X-ray chest, except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The X-ray shows the presence of a miliary shadow, which is not typically seen in cases of Wegener's granulomatosis.
  • Wegener's granulomatosis radiographically shows variable features. 
  • Most common are nodules with/without cavity, reticulonodular interstitial infiltrates, pulmonary haemorrhage, and peripheral wedge-like consolidation.

Miliary shadow refers to innumerable, small (1-4 mm) pulmonary nodules scattered throughout the lungs. It is seen in -

  • Miliary tuberculosis (Option A ruled out)
  • Histoplasmosis (Option B ruled out)
  • Coccidioidomycosis (Option C ruled out)
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Pneumoconiosis - coal workers' pneumoconiosis and silicosis
  • Healed varicella
  • Long-standing MS can lead to pulmonary hemosiderosis
  • Alveolar microlithiasis
  • Papillary and medullary Ca thyroid

questions.text: A young man with pulmonary tuberculosis presents with massive recurrent hemoptysis. For angiographic treatment, which vascular structure should be evaluated first?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bronchial arteries are the most common source of massive hemoptysis in chronic inflammatory lung diseases such as tuberculosis.
  • This is due to hypertrophy and neovascularisation of these systemic vessels in response to prolonged inflammation.
  • Bronchial artery embolisation (BAE) is the preferred first-line angiographic intervention in these cases.

Explanation of other options:

Pulmonary artery (Option A): Although the pulmonary arteries are part of the pulmonary circulation, they are a much less common source of life-threatening hemoptysis in tuberculosis.

Pulmonary vein (Option C): These are passive conduits for oxygenated blood back to the left atrium and are rarely if ever, implicated in hemoptysis.

Superior vena cava (Option D): Not a source of pulmonary bleeding. It is a major systemic vein, not involved in the bronchial circulation.

questions.text: Eggshell calcification of hilar lymph nodes is most often due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Eggshell calcification

  • Eggshell calcification refers to the thin, peripheral calcification of lymph nodes, particularly in the hilar or mediastinal regions.
  • It is classically associated with the following conditions, best remembered by the mnemonic "SSHiP-B":
  • Silicosis (Option B)
  • Sarcoidosis (Option A)
  • Histoplasmosis (Option C)
  • Post-radiation lymphoma
  • Blastomycosis

Among these, silicosis is the most classically associated cause.

(A radiograph of silicosis is given below for reference.)

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with fever, dry cough, breathlessness and night sweats. On chest X-ray, the following findings are seen. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy in a young patient with fever, dry cough, and breathlessness is highly suggestive of sarcoidosis.

Chest X-ray findings characteristic of sarcoidosis include:

  • Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
  • Right paratracheal lymphadenopathy
  • "1, 2, 3 sign" → Garland triad
  • Eggshell calcification of lymph nodes (in chronic cases)

On CT - Galaxy sign

On Gallium-67 scan → Lambda sign in thorax (B) → Panda sign in face (A)

Explanation of other options:

Hypersensitive pneumonitis (Option A): Typically presents with diffuse ground-glass opacities or nodular infiltrates rather than symmetrical hilar lymphadenopathy.

Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) (Option C): Usually affects women of childbearing age and shows cystic changes, not hilar adenopathy.

Tuberculosis (Option D): May cause lymphadenopathy, but classically shows upper lobe cavitary lesions or consolidation rather than symmetrical hilar and paratracheal node enlargement.

questions.text: The following Appearance on HRCT is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:-

  • Signet Ring Appearance and TramTrack Appearance, on HRCT, are suggestive of Bronchiectasis.
  • High-resolution CT (HRCT) is sensitive for detecting bronchiectasis.

Signs of bronchiectasis on HRCT include:

  • Dilated and Irregular Bronchi: Enlarged and distorted airways, often seen as dilated bronchi with thickened walls.
  • Tram-Tracking Sign: Parallel linear opacities along the dilated bronchi, resembling tram tracks.
  • Cylinder and Signet Ring Signs: Cross-sectional images may show cylindrical or tubular bronchi (cylinder sign) and dilated bronchi with surrounding collapsed lung (signet ring sign).

Explanation of other options:

Aspergilloma/Fungus ball (Option B) shows the presence of Monod sign (Lucency around the fungal ball, which changes position with a change in the position of the patient.

Hydatid cysts (Option C) result from infection by the Echinococcus species and can result in cyst formation anywhere in the body. Floating membrane, Sign/water Lilly sign/Camalotte sign are commonly seen.

Lung abscess (Option D): Large pulmonary cavity with a small dependent air-fluid level within the cavity.

questions.text: Hampton's Hump is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hampton's Hump is seen in Pulmonary embolism
  • Other radiological signs seen in Pulmonary embolism are 
    • Westermark sign
    • Knuckle sign/Palla's sign
    • Melting sign
    • Fleishner's sign.

Chest X-ray Findings of PTE

  • IOC for PTE→ CT - Angiography
  • Gold standard confirmatory pulmonary angiography
  • Echo findings in PTE→ McConnell sign - RV hypokinesia with apical sparing
  • IOC for PTE in pregnancy or iodine allergies → V/Q Scan

Before V/Q Scan, CXR should be normal

Explanation of other options:

Tuberculosis (Option B): In the initial stages, presents with X-ray findings of hilar lymphadenopathy and consolidation, followed by fibrosis. It will not present with Hampton's Hump.

Hydatid cysts (Option C): Results from infection by the Echinococcus species and can result in cyst formation anywhere in the body. Floating membrane Sign /water lily sign/Camalotte sign are commonly seen.

Pneumonia (Option D) shows a lobar consolidation with air bronchogram in chest X-ray.

questions.text: Mc Connells Sign on Echocardiography is a feature of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pulmonary thromboembolism

  • McConnell's signis defined as hyperdynamic wall motion in the apex of the right ventricle (RV) with akinesis or hypokinesis in the mid-free wall segment.
  • It is typically observed in patients with acute pulmonary embolism (PE) and is considered highly specific for this condition.
  • The finding of McConnell's sign suggests acute RV pressure overload due to acute pulmonary artery hypertension, which is a characteristic feature of acute PE.

Explanation of other options:

HOCM (Option B) typically presents with asymmetric septal hypertrophy and dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. It is associated with Banana shaped ventricle.

Myocardial infarction (Option C): Myocardial infarction can lead to regional wall motion abnormalities on echocardiography.

Pericardial effusion (Option D): Pericardial effusion can cause compression of the cardiac chambers, leading to tamponade physiology, which may be evident on echocardiography. X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac shadow with a water bottle sign.

questions.text: The following chest X-ray was obtained from a patient with complaints of difficulty in breathing. He was admitted with chest pain, and the ECG is suggestive of ST elevation. Comment on the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The X-ray shows the presence of Bilateral Peri-Hilar Batwing Opacities, which are seen in the case of Acute Pulmonary Oedema following heart failure.
  • Pulmonary oedema is defined as an abnormal accumulation of fluid in the extravascular compartments of the lung.

Features of pulmonary interstitial oedema:

  • Peri-bronchial cuffing and perihilar haze
  • Septal lines/Kerley lines
  • Thickening of interlobar fissures
  • Pulmonary venous engorgement - stag's antler sign
  • Airspace opacification classically in a batwing distribution
  • May have air bronchograms
  • Pleural effusions and fluid in interlobar fissures (including 'vanishing' pulmonary pseudotumour)
  • Increased cardio-thoracic ratio/cardiac silhouette size (assessing for an underlying cardiogenic cause)

The image below is a chest X-ray showing thickened interlobular septa (Kerley B) at the base of the right lower lobe, bronchial wall thickening (cuffing), overall distended veins, and a small pleural effusion with fluid in the interlobar fissures.

Explanation of other options:

Pleural effusion (Option A) of the right side. This is the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space. On a chest X-ray, pleural effusion typically appears as a homogenous opacity that starts at the lung base and rises towards the axilla in a meniscus shape (Ellis curve). It may obscure the costophrenic angle and cause a shift of the mediastinum if large.

Pneumothorax (Option C): Trachea shift to opposite side, Deep sulcus sign

Pulmonary embolism (Option D) Wedge shaped filling defect in CTPA, Hampton's hump, westermark sign, pallas sign, Chang sign.

questions.text: Early change of pulmonary edema in CXR:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Kerley B lines

  • Kerley B lines are thin, horizontal lines seen at the lung periphery, especially at the costophrenic angles, representing thickened interlobular septa due to interstitial oedema.
  • They are considered one of the earliest radiographic features of pulmonary oedema.

Order of changes in Pulmonary oedema,

  • Cephalization (increased vascularity of upper lobar veins) - @ 12-19 mm Hg - stage 1 pulmonary oedema
  • Kerley lines (interstitial oedema) followed by pleural effusion - @ 20 mm Hg - stage 2 pulmonary oedema
  • Alveolectasis/batwing appearance, perihilar fluffy opacities - @ 25 mm Hg - stage 3 pulmonary oedema.

Explanation of Other Options:

Bat wing appearance (Option A): This refers to bilateral perihilar alveolar infiltrates, giving a butterfly or bat-wing pattern on CXR. Seen in alveolar (late-stage) pulmonary oedema, typically when pulmonary capillary pressure exceeds 25 mmHg.It is not the earliest finding, but a sign of progressive fluid accumulation.

Pleural effusion (Option B): This occurs after interstitial oedema, usually in later stages when fluid leaks into the pleural space. Frequently seen in cardiogenic pulmonary oedema, often bilateral. Appears after Kerley B lines and cephalization in the natural progression.

Ground-glass lung fields (Option D): Ground-glass opacities are more common on HRCT and suggest partial alveolar filling. Not typically visible on early plain radiographs.

Seen in various conditions, including ARDS, viral pneumonia, and interstitial lung disease, not specific or early for pulmonary oedema.

choices.text: Due to lymphatic engorgement and oedema of septa

questions.text: All are features of Kerley A lines except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Kerley A lines are Perihilar Lines where whereas Kerley B lines are thin horizontal parallel lines perpendicular to the pleura at the base of the Lungs.
  • Kerley lines on a chest X-ray are thin linear opacities that can be associated with congestive heart failure (CHF).

They are often classified into three types:

  • Interstitial Kerley B Lines: Appear as short, horizontal lines at the lung periphery.
  • Indicate interstitial oedema, common in CHF.
  • Septal Lines (Kerley A Lines): Vertical lines extending from the hilum to the periphery. Kerley A lines are also seen in CHF. (Option D ruled out)
  • Result from fluid accumulation in the interlobular septa.
  • Kerley A lines represent thickened interlobular septa. (Option A ruled out)
  • They are due to fluid accumulation along lymphatic channels in the central connective tissue. (Option B ruled out)
  • These appear as longer, unbranching lines extending from the hilum toward the lung periphery.

Peribronchial Cuffing (Kerley A Lines):

In CHF:

  • X-ray findings often include cardiomegaly (enlarged heart).
  • Increased vascular markings due to fluid retention.
  • Pleural effusions may be present.

questions.text: Fallen Lung sign is a feature of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fallen Lung Sign refers to the collapsed lung falling away from the hilum and lying dependently in the thoracic cavity (usually posteriorly in a supine patient or inferiorly in an upright patient).
  • The "fallen lung sign" is indeed a feature of a fractured bronchus.

Explanation of other options:

Pneumothorax (Option A): This is the presence of air in the pleural space, which leads to lung collapse. On a chest X-ray, pneumothorax appears as an area without lung markings between the lung margin and the chest wall. Deep sulcus sign. There may be a visible line representing the collapsed lung, and the affected side may appear more radiolucent.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (Option B) is when there is an abnormal opening or defect in the diaphragm (pleuroperitoneal membrane), allowing abdominal organs to herniate into the chest cavity.

Upper lobe collapse (Option C): Golden S sign - horizontal fissure pushed down and medially by right upper lobe collapse due to bronchogenic tumour compressing the airway (only on the right side due to presence of horizontal fissure).

questions.text: A 48-year-old female presented with gradually increasing difficulty in breathing for the past 6 months. She is on methotrexate for rheumatoid arthritis. What is the investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario of respiratory symptoms along with the history of rheumatoid arthritis is suggestive of interstitial lung disease (ILD).
  • High-resolution CT is the investigation of choice for ILD. It is the standard technique for the evaluation of diffuse parenchymal lung diseases.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a known cause of secondary ILD.
  • Methotrexate may contribute to pulmonary toxicity.

Usual intestinal pneumonia

  • Subpleural honeycombing
  • Traction bronchiectasis
  • Reticulations

Explanation of other options:

MRI (Option A) and PET (Option B) are not the investigations to confirm the diagnosis of interstitial lung disease (ILD); in most of the lung pathologies, the investigation of choice is HRCT.

Chest x-ray (Option D) is used in the initial assessment of chest pathologies, whereas to confirm them, HRCT is the preferred modality.

questions.text: A 55 Year old male with progressive shortness of breath shows traction bronchiectasis, bibasal fibrosis with volume loss of lungs on HRCT, Barium swallow shows dilated patulous esophagus, most likely cause is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The combination of findings of progressive shortness of breath, traction bronchiectasis, bibasal fibrosis with volume loss of lungs on HRCT, and dilated, patulous oesophagus on barium swallow points towards scleroderma as the most likely cause.
  • Scleroderma, or systemic sclerosis, is a connective tissue disorder characterised by fibrosis and vascular abnormalities.
  • It can affect multiple organs, including the lungs and oesophagus, leading to symptoms such as shortness of breath and oesophageal dysfunction.
  • Traction bronchiectasis and bibasal fibrosis are common findings in scleroderma-related interstitial lung disease, and oesophageal dysmotility can result in a dilated oesophagus on imaging.

Explanation of other options:-

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option A) patient usually presents with joint involvement as a predominant feature along with Respiratory symptoms suggestive of interstitial lung disease (ILD), whereas the given history barium swallow features are suggestive of Scleroderma.

Wegener's granulomatosis (Option B) radiographically shows variable features. Most common are nodules with/without cavity, reticulonodular interstitial infiltrates, pulmonary haemorrhage, and peripheral wedge-like consolidation.

Tuberculosis (Option D) in the initial stages presents with X-ray findings of hilar lymphadenopathy and consolidation, followed by fibrosis.

questions.text: A CXR of an infant, weaned off a ventilator, is given. Probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given CXR shows thin-walled cystic spaces within the lung parenchyma, containing air, called pneumatoceles and are most commonly due to Aureus infection, usually seen in infants.
  • Pneumatoceles are intrapulmonary air-filled cystic spaces that can have a variety of sizes and appearances. They may contain air-fluid levels.

Causes of pneumatocele formation:

  • Staphylococcus aureus (most common)
  • Klebsiella
  • Kerosene poisoning

Lung injury (most commonly ventilator-induced)

  • Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia

Explanation of other options:

Klebsiella pneumoniae (Option A), Aka Friedlander Pneumonia, shows a bulging fissure sign. Consolidation is spreading rapidly, causing lobar expansion and bulging of the adjacent fissure inferiorly.

Haemophilus influenza (Option B): Round pneumonia is seen in children with a hazy margin and mass-like opacity, mainly in the middle lobes.

Pneumococcus (Option D) causes community-acquired pneumonia and shows as a lobar consolidation with air bronchogram in chest X-ray.

questions.text: A 30-year-old alcoholic was admitted with complaints of fever and cough of 5 days duration. X-ray taken is shown below. What is the most probable etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Klebsiella pneumonia

  • The chest X-ray reveals dense right upper lobe consolidation with a bulging horizontal fissure, which is a classic radiological sign of Klebsiella pneumoniae
  • Alcoholic with acute fever, cough, red currant jelly sputum and heterogeneous opacity (air bronchogram).
  • Klebsiella is known for necrotising pneumonia and may progress to abscess or cavitation.
  • Classically affects the upper lobes due to gravity-dependent aspiration in alcoholics.
  • The "bulging fissure" is highly suggestive but not pathognomonic.

Explanation of other options:

Pneumococcus (Option A) causes community-acquired pneumonia and shows as a lobar consolidation with air bronchogram in chest X-ray.

Pneumatoceles (Option B) are the most common Chest X-ray findings of Staph. Aureus infection is usually seen in infants.

Tuberculosis (Option D) in the initial stages presents with X-ray findings of hilar lymphadenopathy and consolidation, followed by fibrosis.

choices.text: Calcification is commonly seen in pulmonary hydatid cysts.
Pulmonary hydatid cysts never show an air-fluid level
Pulmonary hydatid cysts do not usually calcify
The 'rising sun' sign is not seen in pulmonary hydatid disease

questions.text: The chest X-ray shown below is from a patient presenting with cough and chest pain. Based on the radiological findings, identify the true statement regarding pulmonary hydatid disease:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hydatid cysts result from infection by the Echinococcus species and can result in cyst formation anywhere in the body.

  • Echinococcus granulosus species is the most common.
  • They typically do not calcify. (Option A ruled out)
  • Calcification of hydatid cyst occurs in tissues not favour its growth.
  • Lungs provide a favourable environment, hence calcification never occurs in normal lungs.
  • They appear as well-defined, round or oval cystic lesions with thin, smooth walls on chest X-rays.

Other radiographic features include:

  • Air-fluid level (Option B ruled out)
  • Water lily sign/cama lote sign: air-fluid level with a floating membrane
  • Double wall
  • Rising sun sign/serpent sign - a double-wall, dry cyst with crumpled membranes lying at its bottom. (Option D ruled out)
  • Empty cyst sign - when all the contents are removed.

questions.text: Ground Glass appearance On Chest X-ray is a feature of ____
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hyaline membrane disease, also known as respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), is a condition that primarily affects premature newborns.
  • It occurs due to the insufficient production of surfactant, a substance that helps keep the small air sacs in the lungs (alveoli) open.
  • Without enough surfactant, the alveoli collapse, leading to difficulty in breathing and inadequate oxygenation of the blood.
  • On a chest X-ray, hyaline membrane disease typically presents with a ground-glass appearance.

Chest X-Ray features:

  • Whiteout lung
  • Lung volume decreased

CT- Diffuse Ground Glass

  • This term describes the hazy, diffuse opacification of the lung fields, giving the impression of ground glass. This appearance is caused by the accumulation of proteinaceous material and cellular debris within the alveoli.
  • Treatment often involves providing supplemental oxygen and administering surfactant replacement therapy to improve lung function.

Explanation of other options:

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (Option A): When there is an abnormal opening or defect in the diaphragm (pleuroperitoneal membrane), allowing abdominal organs to herniate into the chest cavity.

Transient tachypnea of newborn (Option B) is seen commonly in a full-term baby delivered by LSCS with a normal or increased lung volume with a lamellar, perihilar streaky linear collection/sunray, usually disappears within the next 48 hours.

Pan-lobular emphysema (Option D) is a diffused decreased attenuation in the lobules is suggestive of pan-lobular emphysema and is commonly associated with α1 antitrypsin deficiency. Affects most commonly the lower lobes.

questions.text: A newborn baby was having difficulty breathing. On evaluation, there were multiple air fluid levels noted in the left hemithorax as shown in the image. What would be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presence of multiple air-fluid levels in the left hemithorax of a newborn baby with difficulty breathing suggests congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is a condition in which there is an abnormal opening or defect in the diaphragm (pleuroperitoneal membrane), allowing abdominal organs to herniate into the chest cavity.
  • This herniation can compress the lungs and interfere with their development, leading to respiratory distress after birth.
  • The presence of air-fluid levelson imaging, such as a chest X-ray, is a characteristic finding in CDH due to the displacement of abdominal organs into the thoracic cavity, which can cause bowel loops to become filled with air and fluid.

X-ray of a child with CDH:

Explanation of other options:

Necrotising enterocolitis (Option A) radiologically presents with the presence of intrabowel gas shadow and the presence of gas in portal veins, whereas the given X-ray shows the presence of bowel shadows in the thoracic cavity.

Respiratory distress syndrome (Option C) radiologically presents with whiteout lungs, whereas the given X-ray shows the presence of bowel shadows in the thoracic cavity.

Oesophageal atresia (Option D) presents with drooling of saliva along with coiling of the NG tube in the mouth, which can be appreciated radiologically, whereas the given X-ray shows the presence of bowel shadows in the thoracic cavity.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with a persistent cough that has not responded to antibiotics. He was frequently hospitalised past few years with repeated pulmonary infections; the CXR obtained is shown below. What will you do next to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Chest Radiograph shows a triangular opacity near the left pericardiac region, along with the history of repeated pulmonary infections in a child suggests towards pulmonary sequestration.
  • CT angiography is the investigation of choice to confirm this diagnosis, as it delineates the aberrant systemic arterial supply—typically from the thoracic or abdominal aorta—making it crucial for both diagnosis and preoperative planning.
  • Pulmonary sequestration refers to the aberrant formation of segmental lung tissue that has no connection with the bronchial tree or pulmonary arteries.

There are two types:

  • intralobar sequestration
  • Extralobar sequestration 

Pulmonary Sequestration has a systemic arterial supply, which is usually a branch of the aorta:

Explanation of other options:

Plain CT chest (Option B): Can detect abnormal lung parenchyma, but cannot reliably identify the anomalous blood supply.

Ultrasound chest (Option C): Not sufficient to evaluate intrathoracic vascular anatomy.

Chest X-ray lateral view (Option D): May provide additional localisation but is not definitive for vascular assessment.

questions.text: Well defined lesion in the lung with popcorn calcification on X-ray is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Popcorn calcification on X-ray is seen in pulmonary hamartoma.

Hamartoma

  • Popcorn calcification is seen in pulmonary hamartoma.
  • Popcorn calcificationis defined as a pattern of calcification in rings and arcs that resembles popped corn kernels.
  • The presence of fat in a well-circumscribed solitary pulmonary nodule that does not demonstrate significant growth is pathognomonic of a pulmonary hamartoma.

Chest x-ray showing pulmonary hamartoma:

Explanation of other options:

Hydatid cysts (Option B) result from infection by the Echinococcus species and can result in cyst formation anywhere in the body. Floating membrane Sign/water lily sign/Camalotte sign are commonly seen.

Lung abscess (Option C): Large pulmonary cavity with a small dependent air-fluid level within the cavity.

Lung cancer (Option D) can present with various radiological findings depending on the type and stage, but common features include a focal mass or nodule within the lung parenchyma, irregular margins, associated with bronchial obstruction, and may show invasion into adjacent structures.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man with a history of smoking presented with pain in the right arm. There is also evidence of ptosis. Chest X-ray is given, likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical features of shoulder/arm pain and ptosis point toward Horner's syndrome, which is classically associated with a Pancoast tumour -a carcinoma located at the lung apex.

Radiological findings on the chest X-ray may show:

  • A mass in the superior sulcus (apex) of the lung
  • Possible rib or vertebral involvement
  • Blurring of the upper lung margin
  • Pancoast tumours commonly involve the brachial plexus, sympathetic chain, and adjacent ribs, leading to the characteristic pain and neurological signs.

Explanation of other options:

Upper lobe pneumonia (Option A) presents with a recent history of fever, cough, along with X-ray findings of consolidation with air bronchogram.

Lung Aspergillosis ABPA (Allergic bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis) (Option B) is seen in immunocompromised patients. It presents with mucoceles or Bronchoceles and gives an appearance of finger-in-glove opacities and upper lobe bronchiectasis.

Superior vena cava obstruction (SVCO)(Option D) can occur from extrinsic compression, intrinsic stenosis, or thrombosis of the superior vena cava. Symptoms include facial and neck swelling, facial flushing, bilateral upper extremity swelling, neurological signs, dyspnea, headache, and cough. Whereas the given history with Horner's syndrome and upper lobe involvement in X-ray is suggestive of Pancoast Tumour.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pancoast tumour = apical lung carcinoma with neurovascular involvement.
  • Associated with Horner’s syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis).
  • Seen as an apical opacity on chest X-ray with corresponding clinical signs.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presented with complaints of weight loss and decreased appetite. A routine chest X-ray was done and is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The chest X-ray depicts multiple, large, well-circumscribed, round pulmonary metastases known as cannonball metastases.

The most common primaries to result in pulmonary metastasis in adults include:

  • Breast carcinoma
  • Colorectal carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Uterine leiomyosarcoma
  • Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma

Such findings in an elderly patient with systemic symptoms like weight loss and anorexia make metastasis the most likely diagnosis.

Explanation of other options:

Pulmonary TB (Option A): Typically presents with upper lobe consolidation, cavitations, or nodular opacities. Miliary TB shows numerous small nodules (1-3 mm), not well-defined larger round nodules as seen here.

Pneumonia (Option C): Manifests as areas of consolidation or airspace opacification with ill-defined margins. Multiple well-defined round nodules are not typical of infectious pneumonic processes.

Mesothelioma (Option D): Usually presents with diffuse pleural thickening, pleural effusion, and volume loss. It does not cause multiple well-defined parenchymal nodules.

questions.text: 'Cavitating lesions' in the lung are found in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Squamous cell carcinoma

  • Squamous cell carcinoma most commonly presents with a central cavitating lesion.
  • Regarding primary lung malignancies, non-small-cell lung cancers (NSCLC)have the potential to form cavitary lung lesions or progress in that form. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of NSCLC that cavitates.

(Image showing the cavitations by Squamous cell carcinoma)

Cavitating lesions:

  • Cancers - SCC
  • Abscess
  • Vascular emboli - Septic emboli
  • Infections - TB
  • Trauma

Explanation of other options:

Adenocarcinoma (Option B): This is typically a peripheral tumour and rarely cavitates. It more often appears as a solid nodule or mass without central necrosis.

Small cell carcinoma (Option C): Generally central in location, but rarely cavitates. It is more associated with mediastinal lymphadenopathy and extensive submucosal spread.

Large cell carcinoma (Option D): While large cell carcinoma can occasionally undergo necrosis, cavitation is uncommon. It more frequently presents as a large peripheral mass.

questions.text: Crazy Pavement Appearance on HRCT is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Crazy Pavement Appearance on HRCT due to the interlobar and interlobular septal thickening is seen in Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis and COVID-19.

  • Crazy paving pattern on HRCT, which consists of areas of ground-glass opacification superimposed with a linear reticular pattern, resembling irregular paving stones. This pattern results from the thickening of the interlobular septa and intralobular lines over a background of ground-glass opacity.

Explanation of other options:

Pulmonary alveolar microlithiasis (Option A) is a rare idiopathic condition characterised by widespread intra-alveolar deposition of spherical calcium phosphate microliths (calcospherites).

Pulmonary metastasis (Option C) shows the cannonball appearance on chest X-ray and well-circumscribed, rounded lesions, more often in the periphery of the lung, with prominent pulmonary vessels on CT, and is not associated with Crazy Pavement Appearance on HRCT.

Pulmonary oedema (Option D) will show the bat wing appearance in Chest X-ray is not associated with Crazy Pavement Appearance on HRCT.
